Line 137: Line 137:
Eyewitness reports have suggested that the death toll there may be higher, although confirmation has been difficult due to a ban on media coverage in the area.<ref name="rawstory.com">{{cite web|last=Tencer |first=Daniel |url=http://www.rawstory.com/rs/2011/01/reports-massacre-suez-protests-egypt/ |title=Reports of âmassacreâ in Suez as protests in Egypt move into third day |publisher=Raw Story |date=2011-01-14 |accessdate=2011-01-28}}</ref> Some online activists have referred to Suez as Egypt's [[Sidi Bouzid]], pointing to the Tunisian city around which that nation's 2011 protests centered.<ref>{{cite news|last=Dziadosz|first=Alexander|title=Could Suez be Egypt's Sidi Bouzid?|url=http://af.reuters.com/article/egyptNews/idAFLDE70Q1KZ20110127|accessdate=29 January 2011|newspaper=Reuters|date=27 January 2011}}</ref>
Eyewitness reports have suggested that the death toll there may be higher, although confirmation has been difficult due to a ban on media coverage in the area.<ref name="rawstory.com">{{cite web|last=Tencer |first=Daniel |url=http://www.rawstory.com/rs/2011/01/reports-massacre-suez-protests-egypt/ |title=Reports of âmassacreâ in Suez as protests in Egypt move into third day |publisher=Raw Story |date=2011-01-14 |accessdate=2011-01-28}}</ref> Some online activists have referred to Suez as Egypt's [[Sidi Bouzid]], pointing to the Tunisian city around which that nation's 2011 protests centered.<ref>{{cite news|last=Dziadosz|first=Alexander|title=Could Suez be Egypt's Sidi Bouzid?|url=http://af.reuters.com/article/egyptNews/idAFLDE70Q1KZ20110127|accessdate=29 January 2011|newspaper=Reuters|date=27 January 2011}}</ref>
â
=== Domestic responses ===
+
== Domestic responses ==
[[Mohammed ElBaradei]] called for ousting the regime, as in Tunisia.<ref name="Egyptians should copy Tunisian revolt">[http://www.zawya.com/story.cfm/sidANA20110122T190139ZNYZ32/?relcontent=ZW20110127000145 ElBaradei: Egyptians should copy Tunisian revolt]</ref> He said he was "proud of the protesters" and proud of the military, who by 29 January were the only state force on the streets of Cairo, with police nowhere to be seen. There were numerous individual public displays of affection and respect for soldiers manning positions on the streets.<ref>Al Jazeera English, TV report, 29 January, 12.00 GMT</ref>
[[Mohammed ElBaradei]] called for ousting the regime, as in Tunisia.<ref name="Egyptians should copy Tunisian revolt">[http://www.zawya.com/story.cfm/sidANA20110122T190139ZNYZ32/?relcontent=ZW20110127000145 ElBaradei: Egyptians should copy Tunisian revolt]</ref> He said he was "proud of the protesters" and proud of the military, who by 29 January were the only state force on the streets of Cairo, with police nowhere to be seen. There were numerous individual public displays of affection and respect for soldiers manning positions on the streets.<ref>Al Jazeera English, TV report, 29 January, 12.00 GMT</ref>
Line 150: Line 150:
[[Coptic Orthodox Church of Alexandria|Coptic Orthodox]] Bishop Marcos of [[Shubra El-Khiema]] urged Christians not join the demonstrations, saying that they do not know the goals of those responsible for launching the protests.<ref>{{ar}}{{cite web|url=http://www.almasry-alyoum.com/article2.aspx?ArticleID=285805&IssueID=2025|title=Ø§ÙÙÙØ§Ø¦Ø³ Ø§ÙÙØ³ÙØ­ÙØ© Ø§ÙØ«ÙØ§Ø« ØªØ±ÙØ¶ ÙØ¸Ø§ÙØ±Ø§Øª Ù¢Ù¥ ÙÙØ§ÙØ±.. Ø§ÙØ¨Ø§Ø¨Ø§ Ø´ÙÙØ¯Ø© ÙØ¯Ø¹Ù Ø§ÙØ¬ÙÙØ¹ ÙÙ"Ø§ÙØªÙØ¯Ø¦Ø©"|author=Ø¬ÙØ§Ù Ø¬Ø±Ø¬Ø³ Ø§ÙÙØ²Ø§Ø­Ù|date=26 January 2011|work=|publisher=www.youm7.com|accessdate=29 January 2011}}</ref> In spite of this, a number of young Christian activists joined the protests led by well-known Christians like member of the Wafd Party [[Raymond Lakah]]. Coptic thinker [[Rafiq Habib]] condemned the position of the Church but he stressed that the participation of Copts in the demonstrations are increasing day by day.<ref>{{ar}}{{cite web|url=http://www.aljazeera.net/NR/exeres/1049E146-447D-45F9-800E-7F2A064112E1.htm?GoogleStatID=9|title=Ø§ÙÙÙÙØ³Ø© Ø¨ÙÙØ£Ù Ø¹Ù ÙØ¸Ø§ÙØ±Ø§Øª ÙØµØ±|author=|date=27 January 2011|work=|publisher=ALJazeera|accessdate=29 January 2011}}</ref>
[[Coptic Orthodox Church of Alexandria|Coptic Orthodox]] Bishop Marcos of [[Shubra El-Khiema]] urged Christians not join the demonstrations, saying that they do not know the goals of those responsible for launching the protests.<ref>{{ar}}{{cite web|url=http://www.almasry-alyoum.com/article2.aspx?ArticleID=285805&IssueID=2025|title=Ø§ÙÙÙØ§Ø¦Ø³ Ø§ÙÙØ³ÙØ­ÙØ© Ø§ÙØ«ÙØ§Ø« ØªØ±ÙØ¶ ÙØ¸Ø§ÙØ±Ø§Øª Ù¢Ù¥ ÙÙØ§ÙØ±.. Ø§ÙØ¨Ø§Ø¨Ø§ Ø´ÙÙØ¯Ø© ÙØ¯Ø¹Ù Ø§ÙØ¬ÙÙØ¹ ÙÙ"Ø§ÙØªÙØ¯Ø¦Ø©"|author=Ø¬ÙØ§Ù Ø¬Ø±Ø¬Ø³ Ø§ÙÙØ²Ø§Ø­Ù|date=26 January 2011|work=|publisher=www.youm7.com|accessdate=29 January 2011}}</ref> In spite of this, a number of young Christian activists joined the protests led by well-known Christians like member of the Wafd Party [[Raymond Lakah]]. Coptic thinker [[Rafiq Habib]] condemned the position of the Church but he stressed that the participation of Copts in the demonstrations are increasing day by day.<ref>{{ar}}{{cite web|url=http://www.aljazeera.net/NR/exeres/1049E146-447D-45F9-800E-7F2A064112E1.htm?GoogleStatID=9|title=Ø§ÙÙÙÙØ³Ø© Ø¨ÙÙØ£Ù Ø¹Ù ÙØ¸Ø§ÙØ±Ø§Øª ÙØµØ±|author=|date=27 January 2011|work=|publisher=ALJazeera|accessdate=29 January 2011}}</ref>
â
==== Mubarak dismisses the government ====
+
=== Mubarak dismisses the government ===
On 29 January, in response to the previous days events, President Mubarak spoke on national television after midnight local time for the first time since the protests began. He said in his speech that despite a "point of no return" being crossed, national stability and [[law and order (politics)|law and order]] must prevail, that he had requested the government, formed only months ago, to step down, and that a new government would be formed.<ref>Breaking News. Al Jazeera English. 29 November 1:30 Egypt time</ref><ref>
On 29 January, in response to the previous days events, President Mubarak spoke on national television after midnight local time for the first time since the protests began. He said in his speech that despite a "point of no return" being crossed, national stability and [[law and order (politics)|law and order]] must prevail, that he had requested the government, formed only months ago, to step down, and that a new government would be formed.<ref>Breaking News. Al Jazeera English. 29 November 1:30 Egypt time</ref><ref>

==== Media censorship ====
+
=== Media censorship ===
[[File:Unplug-mubarak.gif|thumb|A [[political cartoon]] by [[Carlos Latuff]] depicting Hosni Mubarak shutting down Internet, and about to be unplugged (ousted) by the country. Many other Latuff drawings about the protests are available at [[:Commons:Category:Carlos Latuff/2011 Egyptian protests|Wikimedia Commons]].]]
[[File:Unplug-mubarak.gif|thumb|A [[political cartoon]] by [[Carlos Latuff]] depicting Hosni Mubarak shutting down Internet, and about to be unplugged (ousted) by the country. Many other Latuff drawings about the protests are available at [[:Commons:Category:Carlos Latuff/2011 Egyptian protests|Wikimedia Commons]].]]
Beginning on the first day of protests the Egyptian government censored most of the [[media of Egypt|media outlets inside Egypt]] and took measures to block social media websites<ref name="Facebook & Twitter Both Blocked in Egypt">{{cite web|author=Sarah Kessler|url=http://mashable.com/2011/01/26/facebook-blocked-in-egypt/|title=Facebook & Twitter Both Blocked in Egypt|publisher=[[Mashable]]|accessdate=2011-01-27}}</ref> which had helped protesters to spread news about the events on the ground. The success of the protests has been partly attributed to the involvement of tech savvy youth all over Egypt who were able to overcome the government blockades on social media.
Beginning on the first day of protests the Egyptian government censored most of the [[media of Egypt|media outlets inside Egypt]] and took measures to block social media websites<ref name="Facebook & Twitter Both Blocked in Egypt">{{cite web|author=Sarah Kessler|url=http://mashable.com/2011/01/26/facebook-blocked-in-egypt/|title=Facebook & Twitter Both Blocked in Egypt|publisher=[[Mashable]]|accessdate=2011-01-27}}</ref> which had helped protesters to spread news about the events on the ground. The success of the protests has been partly attributed to the involvement of tech savvy youth all over Egypt who were able to overcome the government blockades on social media.
Line 319: Line 319:
Despite the internet blackout, Egyptians abroad have been leading initiatives to spread the news that they get by calling their relatives' landlines.
Despite the internet blackout, Egyptians abroad have been leading initiatives to spread the news that they get by calling their relatives' landlines.
â
==== Financial markets ====
+
=== Financial markets ===
On Wednesday 26 January, Egypt's [[CASE 30|EGX]] stock market index fell on speculation the instability would spread.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-01-16/egypt-stocks-drop-most-in-six-weeks-as-tunisia-s-leader-ben-ali-overthrown.html|title=Egypt Stocks Drop Most in Six Weeks on Concern Tunisia Unrest May Spread|publisher=Bloomberg|date=2011-01-16|author=Ahmed A Namatalla}}</ref> The EGX30 has dropped almost 1000 points since 13 January 2011. EGX dropped 6.1% on 26 January, and then another 6.2% on 27 January, before the chief of the stock market temporarily suspended trading<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.reuters.com/article/idUSLDE70Q0PT20110127 |title=Egypt Bourse suspends trade after index slides |publisher=Reuters |date=2011-01-27 |accessdate=2011-01-27}}</ref> due to marked losses in the first minutes of the opening session. The stock index closed the day down by 10.5%.<ref>{{cite web|last=Halzack |first=Sarah |url=http://voices.washingtonpost.com/political-economy/2011/01/riots_in_egypt_weigh_heavily_o.html |title=Political Economy - Egypt riots weigh on the nation's stock market |publisher=Voices.washingtonpost.com |date=2010-04-13 |accessdate=2011-01-29}}</ref>
On Wednesday 26 January, Egypt's [[CASE 30|EGX]] stock market index fell on speculation the instability would spread.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-01-16/egypt-stocks-drop-most-in-six-weeks-as-tunisia-s-leader-ben-ali-overthrown.html|title=Egypt Stocks Drop Most in Six Weeks on Concern Tunisia Unrest May Spread|publisher=Bloomberg|date=2011-01-16|author=Ahmed A Namatalla}}</ref> The EGX30 has dropped almost 1000 points since 13 January 2011. EGX dropped 6.1% on 26 January, and then another 6.2% on 27 January, before the chief of the stock market temporarily suspended trading<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.reuters.com/article/idUSLDE70Q0PT20110127 |title=Egypt Bourse suspends trade after index slides |publisher=Reuters |date=2011-01-27 |accessdate=2011-01-27}}</ref> due to marked losses in the first minutes of the opening session. The stock index closed the day down by 10.5%.<ref>{{cite web|last=Halzack |first=Sarah |url=http://voices.washingtonpost.com/political-economy/2011/01/riots_in_egypt_weigh_heavily_o.html |title=Political Economy - Egypt riots weigh on the nation's stock market |publisher=Voices.washingtonpost.com |date=2010-04-13 |accessdate=2011-01-29}}</ref>
On 28 January, [[Fitch Ratings]] reduced Egypt's rating outlook to negative from stable, saying the upsurge in protests adds uncertainty to the political and economic outlook.<ref name="Bloomberg-Muslim-Brotherhood">{{cite news|url=http://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-01-28/egypt-s-muslim-botherhood-says-police-detain-senior-leaders-after-protests.html|title=Mubarak Faces His Biggest Challenge Amid Nationwide Protests|date=2011-01-28|publisher=Bloomberg|author=Vivian Salama, Ola Galal and Caroline Alexander}}</ref> Egyptian dollar-denominated bond yields also rose to a record high as oil prices rose and global stock market indices sank.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-01-28/asian-stocks-fall-for-first-time-in-five-days-on-japan-outlook-oil-slides.html|title=Oil Jumps, Stocks Retreat Amid Protests in Egypt|publisher=Bloomberg|author=Stephen Kirkland|date=2011-01-28}}</ref> International gold prices jumped more than US$20, the most in 12 weeks, to $1341.<ref>{{cite web|last=Tian |first=Yi |url=http://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-01-28/gold-rises-from-lowest-since-october-on-outlook-for-u-s-interest-rates.html |title=Gold Jumps Most in 12 Weeks on Haven Demand Amid Egypt Tensions |publisher=Bloomberg |date= |accessdate=2011-01-29}}</ref> The price of oil rose US$3.70 (4.3%) to US$89.34 on concern the instability would spread.<ref>{{cite web|last=Habiby |first=Margot |url=http://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-01-28/crude-oil-climbs-from-eight-week-low-in-new-york-as-u-s-economy-expands.html |title=Crude Oil Surges the Most Since 2009 on Concern Egyptian Unrest to Spread |publisher=Bloomberg |date=2008-09-26 |accessdate=2011-01-29}}</ref>
On 28 January, [[Fitch Ratings]] reduced Egypt's rating outlook to negative from stable, saying the upsurge in protests adds uncertainty to the political and economic outlook.<ref name="Bloomberg-Muslim-Brotherhood">{{cite news|url=http://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-01-28/egypt-s-muslim-botherhood-says-police-detain-senior-leaders-after-protests.html|title=Mubarak Faces His Biggest Challenge Amid Nationwide Protests|date=2011-01-28|publisher=Bloomberg|author=Vivian Salama, Ola Galal and Caroline Alexander}}</ref> Egyptian dollar-denominated bond yields also rose to a record high as oil prices rose and global stock market indices sank.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-01-28/asian-stocks-fall-for-first-time-in-five-days-on-japan-outlook-oil-slides.html|title=Oil Jumps, Stocks Retreat Amid Protests in Egypt|publisher=Bloomberg|author=Stephen Kirkland|date=2011-01-28}}</ref> International gold prices jumped more than US$20, the most in 12 weeks, to $1341.<ref>{{cite web|last=Tian |first=Yi |url=http://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-01-28/gold-rises-from-lowest-since-october-on-outlook-for-u-s-interest-rates.html |title=Gold Jumps Most in 12 Weeks on Haven Demand Amid Egypt Tensions |publisher=Bloomberg |date= |accessdate=2011-01-29}}</ref> The price of oil rose US$3.70 (4.3%) to US$89.34 on concern the instability would spread.<ref>{{cite web|last=Habiby |first=Margot |url=http://www.bloomberg.com/news/2011-01-28/crude-oil-climbs-from-eight-week-low-in-new-york-as-u-s-economy-expands.html |title=Crude Oil Surges the Most Since 2009 on Concern Egyptian Unrest to Spread |publisher=Bloomberg |date=2008-09-26 |accessdate=2011-01-29}}</ref>
â
==== Rumours of Mubarak's family's departure ====
+
=== Rumours of Mubarak's family's departure ===
[[Gamal Mubarak]], President Hosni Mubarak's sonâwho has been widely tipped as his successorâwas reported by the US-based Arabic website Akhbar al-Arab to have fled to [[London]] with his family on 25 January.<ref name="Beginning of the end">{{cite web|url=http://www.ibtimes.com/articles/105117/20110126/beginning-of-the-end-for-egypt-s-mubarak-as-son-and-wife-flee.htm|title='Beginning of the end' for Egypt's Mubarak as son and wife flee|accessdate=26 January 2011|date=26 January 2011|publisher=[[International Business Times]]}}</ref> Later reports said that Mubarak's family did not, in fact, flee.<ref>{{cite web|last=Norman |first=Joshua |url=http://www.cbsnews.com/8301-503543_162-20029614-503543.html |title=Source: Mubarak Family Hasn't Fled Egypt - World Watch |publisher=CBS News |date= |accessdate=2011-01-26}}</ref> Al Jazeera's reporter in Cairo said that Gamal remained in Cairo and was attending a meeting of the ruling National Democratic Party.<ref name="aljazeera-448"/> On Saturday 29th it was reported that Gamal and [[Alaa Mubarak]] had arrived in London with their respective families.<ref>[http://twitter.com/#!/BBCWorld/status/31381280729862144] BBC World Twitter Feed</ref><!-- Yes, this is just a tweet for a ref. please replace with a better ref when one is published --> Egyptian State Television has denied this report.<ref>{{cite news|l|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/middle_east/9380534.stm|title=Live:Egypt Unrest Day 5|publisher=BBC World News |date= |accessdate=2011-01-29}}</ref><!-- This could also use a less transient source -->
[[Gamal Mubarak]], President Hosni Mubarak's sonâwho has been widely tipped as his successorâwas reported by the US-based Arabic website Akhbar al-Arab to have fled to [[London]] with his family on 25 January.<ref name="Beginning of the end">{{cite web|url=http://www.ibtimes.com/articles/105117/20110126/beginning-of-the-end-for-egypt-s-mubarak-as-son-and-wife-flee.htm|title='Beginning of the end' for Egypt's Mubarak as son and wife flee|accessdate=26 January 2011|date=26 January 2011|publisher=[[International Business Times]]}}</ref> Later reports said that Mubarak's family did not, in fact, flee.<ref>{{cite web|last=Norman |first=Joshua |url=http://www.cbsnews.com/8301-503543_162-20029614-503543.html |title=Source: Mubarak Family Hasn't Fled Egypt - World Watch |publisher=CBS News |date= |accessdate=2011-01-26}}</ref> Al Jazeera's reporter in Cairo said that Gamal remained in Cairo and was attending a meeting of the ruling National Democratic Party.<ref name="aljazeera-448"/> On Saturday 29th it was reported that Gamal and [[Alaa Mubarak]] had arrived in London with their respective families.<ref>[http://twitter.com/#!/BBCWorld/status/31381280729862144] BBC World Twitter Feed</ref><!-- Yes, this is just a tweet for a ref. please replace with a better ref when one is published --> Egyptian State Television has denied this report.<ref>{{cite news|l|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/middle_east/9380534.stm|title=Live:Egypt Unrest Day 5|publisher=BBC World News |date= |accessdate=2011-01-29}}</ref><!-- This could also use a less transient source -->
